div1.p: GENERAL LEE ON FEVER.

Gives Out an Interesting Interview on
the Quemados Situation.

Says His First Duty Is to His Soldiers, and
the Cubans Cannot Complain if Insular
Funds Are Spent to Protect Their Lives--
Says Rain Brought on Disease.

A reporter for THE POST approached
General Lee Sunday on the subject of
yellow fever at Quemados. No sooner
had the subject been broached than the
general abruptly said:

“Would you know a yellow fever baci-
lus if you met it on the road, or else-
where?” “No,” said the reporter. “Then
listen,” said General Lee, and he dictated
the following:

“Quemados is one of the prettiest and
should be one of the healthiest towns in
Cuba. Situated on an elevated plane,
with wide, well-drained macadamized
streets, fringed on each side with shade
trees, it offers no attraction to the yellow
king bacillus and his amarillo cohorts.
Up to its very gates, on every side, 15,000
men of the Seventh army corps formerly
safely dwelled, and today Columbia bar-
racks, with the Seventh cavalry, Eighth
infantry and two batteries of light artil-
lery is close to its northern limits, and
with its fine water supply, splendid sewer
system and high limestone hills overlook-
ing the sea, will successfully, I think, re-
sist all assaults of old bacillus.

“Quemados, however, has one street
which crosses the railroad in the direct-
ion of the barracks and along which are
strung many little shanties and saloons,
rented and operated by non-immunes,
for the purpose of catching the soldier
trade. The unusual fall of heavy rain
this month overflowed the sinks and
made slush of filthy back yards upon
which the fierce rays of a tropical sun
fell. Germs were generated, and the Yel-
low King, or ‘Y. K.’ as the ‘Christian
Scientists’ call him, was removed or re-
leased from the nidus, tainted the local
atmosphere and invaded with poison-
ous breath the lungs of the most recept-
ve, yet unsuspecting people.

Down the street Bacillus pursued his
distructive course. Major Edmunds and
his wife, Captain Hepburn, a signal
corps man who slept in his house, and
others on the same street and within the
pestilential focus fell, before his baneful
blade.

Major Kean, chief surgeon of the de-
partment, and charged with the duty of
riding down disease, frequently marched
into the street to meet the invader Bacil-
lus and shoot the old warrior to death
with medicinal skill and medical juris-
prudence. He was welcomed with ex-
ceeding joy by the ‘Y. K.’ ‘Breathe the
air that I breathe’ said he. ‘Go to my
nidus and see if you can tell where I came
from and where I journey to.’ Today
the chief surgeon is the prisoner of the
‘Y. K.’ and his yellow flag now floats
over his couch.

“Fortunately most of the [unclear]
especially the women and children, left
Quemados last month to spend the sum-
mer in the United States. The order has
been issued, ‘To your tents, oh non-
immunes.’ The houses and grounds oc-
cupied by them have been, thoroughly
disinfected, so that it is hoped, that the
‘Y. K.’ will cease firing for want of am-
munition and die for want of nourish-
ment.

‘Lest we forget, lest we forget,’ the
Cubans should remember the United
States soldier and sailor blood freely
shed and the money from the United
States treasury freely given to relieve
them from Spanish rule, and in return
make no unfriendly comments on insular
funds being spent to protect the lives of
American soldiers and citizens. My first
duty is to the soldiers of my command,
who are here to maintain the peace of
this island and the rights of the people
of every country, and whose welfare and
safety from disease must be most care-
fully looked after.

“And now,” said General Lee, turning
to the reporter, “I do not think any less
of you for not knowing anything of
Bacillus. No man does. The ablest
physician, whether a propounder of new
opinions on other subjects or a dogmatic
theorist, a learned doctrinaire or a reg-
ular old-time doctor knows nothing of
the origin of yellow fever, because its
germs have never been discovered and
they will tell you so. ‘Absolutomente
nada.’ Much is known of the treatment
of the disease when once acquired, and
much too about the necessary measures
to be taken to prevent being sick, as well
as to circumscribe it within its original
focus.

“Oh no, we know nothing of Y. K.,
except that when the bacillus has been
removed from the nidus he is more ter-
rible than any army with banners as he
rides at the head of the germs, flying
proudly a banner upon whose danger-
ous folds we see a powder magazine into
which a lighted match is being thrown,
and the motto, ‘run or rust.’”
NEW ROAD TO QUEMADOS.

Havana Will Soon Have an Excellent Drive
Along the Coast.

The new public road to connect Que-
mados with Havana, and which is to run
by Vedado, is nearly complete.

In a few weeks Havana will have an
excellent drive along the Atlantic, or a
short distance from it, all the way to
Camp Columbia and Quemados.

Heretofore all traffic by vehicles be-
tween Havana and Quemados and Ma-
rianao was by way of Cerro and Puentes
Grandes. By this route there were a
number of hills to cross, and the narrow
cut-up streets through Cerro made travel
very unpleasant. The old road was not
well built and was always in bad condi-
tion, despite the fact that thousands of
dollars had annually to be spent upon it
for repairs, which were always in need.

The new road will be one of the best
and most substantial turnpikes in Cuba.
It is being built of the hardest flint rock
from the new stone crusher, which is put
down about six inches thick, after the
road has been well graded. A compe-
tent engineer is in charge of the work
and is seeing that it is well done.

General Lee is taking a commendable
pride in the new roadway, and is having
the work pushed as rapidly as possible.

Parties who drive over the new road
after it is complete will go to Quemados
by Vedado, over the new bridge on the
Almendares river.
